title: 109_hr867
content: The Act may be cited as the "Openness Promotes Effectiveness in our National Government Act of 2005" or the "OPEN Government Act of 2005". The Freedom of Information Act, signed into law in 1966, emphasizes the importance of informed consent for the functioning of a free government. Justice Black highlighted the need for public understanding of government service in his opinion in Barr v. Matteo. The Freedom of Information Act establishes a strong presumption in favor of disclosure for all government agencies, but in practice, it has not always been upheld. Congress should regularly review the Act to ensure transparency and openness in government operations. The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) should be regularly reviewed under 5, United States Code to ensure government transparency and accessibility to the American people based on the right to know. The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) is being amended to protect the fee status for news media by considering prior publication history and intent to distribute information. Additionally, the amendment allows for the recovery of attorney fees and litigation costs. The amendment to the Freedom of Information Act allows for the recovery of attorney fees and litigation costs for complainants who have substantially prevailed in obtaining relief. Additionally, disciplinary actions are introduced for arbitrary and capricious rejections of requests. SEC. 5 amends Section 552(a)(4)(F) of title 5, United States Code to introduce disciplinary actions for arbitrary and capricious rejections of requests. The Attorney General and Special Counsel are required to notify Congress and submit reports on civil actions taken. The amendment to Section 552(a)(6)(A)(i) of title 5, United States Code establishes a 20-day time limit for agencies to respond to requests, starting from the date of receipt without tolling. The effective date of this amendment is one year after enactment. Additionally, if an agency fails to meet the time limit, they cannot assert any exemption under subsection (b) unless disclosure is made. The amendment establishes a 20-day time limit for agencies to respond to requests under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. Agencies cannot assert exemptions unless disclosure endangers national security, discloses protected information, or is prohibited by law. A court may waive this if the agency shows good cause for non-compliance. SEC. 7. INDIVIDUALIZED TRACKING NUMBERS FOR REQUESTS AND STATUS INFORMATION. Section 552(a) of title 5, United States Code is amended to require each agency to assign individualized tracking numbers for information requests, provide the tracking number to the requester within 10 days, and offer a telephone or Internet service for status updates on the request. The amendment made by this section will take effect 1 year after the enactment of the Act and will apply to information requests under section 552 of title 5, United States Code filed after the effective date. SEC. 8 amends Section 552(b) of title 5, US Code, by specifying exemptions from disclosure by statute, with certain criteria to be met. SEC. 9 outlines reporting requirements. Section 552(e)(1) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include data on active requests, response times, and fee status requests. The amendment to Section 552(e)(1) of title 5, United States Code requires agencies to report data on active requests, response times, and fee status determinations for requests. Agencies must differentiate between first person requests for personal records and other types of requests when reporting the total number of requests filed. SEC. 10 amends Section 552(f) of title 5, US Code to include information maintained by a private entity under a contract with an agency as agency records. SEC. 11 establishes the Office of Government Information Services. The Office of Government Information Services is established within the Administrative Conference of the United States to review agency policies and compliance with section 552, conduct audits, and recommend policy changes to improve administration. The Office of Government Information Services is tasked with reviewing agency compliance with section 552 and recommending policy changes to improve administration. The President aims to enhance compliance by ensuring adequate funding and offering mediation services as an alternative to litigation. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 12. ACCESSIBILITY OF CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE INFORMATION. The amendments made by this section shall take effect 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to Congress on the implementation and use of section 214 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. This report includes information on the number of private sector entities and state/local agencies providing records to the Department, requests for access to records, and recommendations for improving the collection and analysis of sensitive information related to critical infrastructure vulnerabilities and threats. The report to Congress will cover vulnerabilities and threats to critical infrastructure, as well as the response to these issues. It will also assess whether withholding information has improved the protection of critical infrastructure. The report will be unclassified, with the possibility of a classified annex. SEC. 13. REPORT ON PERSONNEL POLICIES RELATED TO FOIA. The Office of Personnel Management must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, examining potential changes to executive branch personnel policies to encourage Federal employees to fulfill their duties under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The report will also consider whether compliance with section 552 should be a factor in personnel performance evaluations and if a specific employment classification series for compliance with sections 552 and 552a of title 5 is necessary. The Office of Personnel Management must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, examining potential changes to executive branch personnel policies to encourage Federal employees to fulfill their duties under sections 552 and 552a of title 5, United States Code. The report will consider establishing compliance, pay rates for officials, career advancement tracks, and awareness training for Federal employees.
